Java.name: IsMember
Java.template: $package   import plm.universe.bat.BatTest; import plm.universe.cons.ConsEntity; import plm.universe.cons.RecList;  public class IsMember extends ConsEntity { 	@Override 	public void run(BatTest t) { 		RecList parameter = RecList.fromArray( (int[]) t.getParameter(0) ); 		t.setResult( isMember( parameter, (int)t.getParameter(1) ) ); 	}  $body }

Scala.name: IsMember

Python.name: IsMember

initialWorlds.name: isMember
initialWorlds.about:
ConsWorld

This world allows you to experiment with the recursive lists, as they were first introduced in Lisp. It is very similar to the BatWorld, but you are supposed to write recursive functions working on recursive strings. Since Java does not provide such a construct natively, the ConsWorld defines recursive lists of type RecList.

Any given such list is either the empty list (noted null), or an integer followed by a list. If a list is not empty, you can retrieve its first integer with list.head and the list containing its other parameters with list.tail. Of course, the empty list has no head nor the tail, so trying to access these elements will result in an (unpleasant) error message.

To build your own list, you need to concatenate a head and a tail as follows: cons(head, tail)

So, in summary, you can solve every exercises of this lesson with the following constructs.

  • The empty list: 
    null
  • Get the first element of l 
    l.head
  • Get the rest of the list, when the first element is removed: 
    l.tail
  • Build a list from a value and a list: 
    cons(value, list)

answerWorlds.name: isMember
